comments.commentBody: I have not read the book, and my guess would be that most people commenting here have not either. I can see that the work raises many questions, and does not negate the idea that comparing IQ scores between different age and societal groups is quite tricky, and the norms vary--requiring tests to be constantly re-standardized. Certain types of intelligence may improve more than others (i.e. verbal vs. analytical). From what I've read, Flynn is as much a political philosopher as a psychologist. This book may have a certain "feel good" effect, so we can perhaps pat ourselves on the back, but we probably shouldn't spend too much time congratulating ourselves. We are still fighting over some of the same political fiascoes as our Revolutionary Era ancestors. Based on another review, Flynn apparently cautions, "...it would probably be better to say that we are more modern." He emphasizes that (some of us) see the world through "scientific spectacles."Also there are a number of geographical variations that are difficult to explain. For a review with a somewhat different take, see: ( http://online.wsj.com/article/SB1000087239639044418000457801848006182460... ).

I am from Hyderabad. I don't know where in India you are from. Ravi Shankar donated all his prize money to Ravi Shankar Foundation which established Ravi Shankar Institute for Music and Performing Arts at 7 Chanakyapuri, New Delhi 110021. Indian Traditional Music is taught there in Indian Traditional way i.e. Gurukul system. Students from India as well as U.S. benefit from that school. India has dozens if not hundreds of music colleges and schools where one can learn Sitar. Just take a walk in the gullies of Varanasi, and you will find Sitar teachers.

Ravi Shankar is the musician to the world,and he was a legend both in India and the U.S. You say that right from his adolescence he was wandering all over the world. Actually, he was only ten when he joined the dance troup of his brother Uday Shankar, and toured the world. The world is fortunate that he imbibed the Indian music in a way which enabled him to present to the rest of the world, which he saw even before learning music.

I don't know on what basis you can say Ravi Shankar came to India and exploited its resources. He certainly didn't take his monwy with him to heaven. It is there wth the Foundation. Bulk of it is there with his center in the heart of New Delhi, India.

I was still in grammar school in 1967 when I saw and heard Pandit Shankar one evening on the Boston public television station.  I'd never heard anything like his music and I fell in love with it on the spot.  Some months later I was in the old G. Fox department store in Hartford CT and I found three of his records for sale.  I bought them and I wore them out listening to them again and again on my parents' cheap stereo.  Some years later a family moved into my hometown who had just spent a year in India on a NYS Education Department grant.  The lady of the house had studied the sarod with a then very young virtuoso named Amjad Ali Khan -- an enormously talented musician and scion of a long line of royal court musicians.  Her name is Joan Ferguson.  She very kindly and generously gave me lessons on the sitar.  By a happy chance Joan and her husband Henry moved here to Albany where I live some years ago.  And one memorable evening, Ustad Amjad Ali was here in Albany for a concert at SUNY and while he was here he gave a private concert at their home and gave a never to be forgotten performance by a very great artist for a small group of friends.  . Priceless.

I attended a performance by Shankar held at the National Cathedral in DC -- had to be late 60s. I didn't entirely understand the music, but the whole experience was amazing and beautiful as the sounds -- all the reverbs from the strings -- echoed around the cathedral. Very cool. Music is an idiom that transcends nationality or ethnicity or class or whatever category you want to break humanity up into, and we need more cross-cultural ambassadors like Shankar.

I always love your columns, even now that I don't get to read about a dog named Seamus caged on a car-top. (I have a dog named Seamus, and all through the last election cycle experienced complicated feelings, exacerbated by your columns, about why Romney should lose.) This one is fun.

Don't you think that the zombie vs. vampire thing is a redux of the rock vs. disco thing in the 70s and 80s, male energy vs. female energy, with the male energy winning out because guys still control the culture? Guys like zombies because they get like zombies, with their beer and football and cars, while girls like vampires because they are cute and svelte and dark, and want to cuddle but could also bite your carotid vein if the moon struck in the wrong way.

That said, it does seem certain to me that the world will end on 12/21, at least for some people. Creating end of the world scenarios seems to be one of the many ways we deal with our dread of what inevitably happens to each of us, at some point, generally not of our choosing, though some states are starting to change those laws. I'm hoping my own personal apocalypse is still a few years off, and that when it finally comes I won't be a zombie or vampire, but will turn into pure light.

We don't have more Einsteins today than we did a hundred years ago, though we have a purportedly higher IQ population, and larger population to draw from. The fact is, the Flynn effect suggests that IQ has little to do with intelligence.

IQ in a cohort is analogous instead to one's rank in high school graduating class. It is difficult to compare these across time or distance. Is the topper in a school today better than one from a generation ago? There is grade inflation perhaps. What we can say is that the subjects and skills taught today are different from yesteryears, perhaps more sophisticated.

Yours are subjective examples of stupidity. The fact that you sight noises and sounds speaks to a tiny portion of what makes up intelligence and creativity. It seems you are more equating annoyance stupidity.

A elderly relative by marriage dropped out of school after eighth grade because her immigrant father did not see any reason for a factory-job bound girl to get a high school diploma. She is not a stupid person but her intellect is stunted and her thoughts easily manipulated.

On the other hand my orphaned uncle also finished school by age 14; he went on to become a pillar of his community, the founder of a community college, a major philanthropist and a very wealthy man who literally started with nothing.

Perhaps the key differences between them were that my uncle was a) a man, b) very handsome and self-confident, and c) a huge reader despite his lack of formal education.

I really wonder what kinds of intelligence people are acquiring when we have become insensitive to ugly architecture, brutal and empty music invading public spaces, general inability to sit still in a quiet room etc. etc. I fail to see how individuals are getting smarter as the culture is getting dumber.

Look at any news program on TV, how it's filled with random noises, mind-deadening music, constant graphic effects, breathless delivery with no pauses between subjects. It's all so stupid. Even Golf broadcasts feature random noises and accelerated camera effects. People are so bored! This is intelligence?

The nearly 50% of Americans who voted against their own interests in the last election, who couldn't connect dots or react to bold lies day after day?

Perhaps the study focused on isolated brain functions taken individually. It certainly wouldn't come to the same conclusions if it looked at the larger picture.
You may be confounding I.Q. with intelligence potential.
I disagree with your refutation that IQ is heavily shaped by culture, but the rest of your point is excellent -- and I don't see why both cannot be true. What am I missing?

Mr. Kristof writes:

"I.Q. is heavily shaped by environment"

This is false.

It's been apparent for some time that raw, computational intelligence is set fairly early on in life. Today’s idea that we should all aspire to something more than physical labor and craftsmanship is a reflection of modern society's tendency to idealize intelligence as somehow more meaningful a trait than imagination or artistic talent.

Education these days fails on two grounds: failing to achieve academically is viewed as somehow a failure as a person, rather than an indication that your strengths lie in other areas; the object of education is not for the talented to excel, but rather for everyone to achieve a base level of mediocrity. Those incapable of even mediocrity (logically, half of the populace, depending on the definition of mediocrity) will never achieve it, regardless, and those who might have been excellent with support will only achieve mediocrity. Intelligence is like any other trait - you have an underlying capacity set by the genetics that you've inherited, but if you don't work it adequately you will never achieve its potential. That's the case for an olympic sprinter, a rocket scientist or a master chef. Today so much effort goes into trying to force children who are not capable to achieve some sort of pretense of average. The tendency is, these days, to reset the bar lower so that even mediocrity is not assured, but 100% pass rates are.

We need our savings to last at least 30 years if I work to 67.

To Charles and others confused by the mess that is our tax code and the ERISA law: Your 401k and other "deferred compensation" plans will be taxed as regular income at the time of distribution.

The key here is that the contributions are defined in law as deferred compensation; therefore, they are treated as normal income in the tax year you take a distribution as it was income earned in 2012, but won't be paid out until retirement. The capital gains rate now or in the future is inconsequential to the taxes you owe when you start pulling money out after you retire. The only way this would change would be for an overhaul of the ERISA regulations.

The only time you could get any kind of special tax rate on gains made in your 401k is in the case of holding company stock that issues a dividend paid directly to the participant. In those cases, depending on how it's classified and other arcane rules, it could be taxed at a lower rate. More often than not, however, it's still considered normal income.

If you are that concerned about your taxes after retirement, you should talk with a licensed financial adviser (which I am not) who has specific knowledge regarding ERISA (employer-sponsored retirement plans) and IRAs. They should be able to tell you about tax risk, how to mitigate it, and what you can do to plan for it, in case you are too close to retirement for drastic changes.

Well, during the presidential campaign, I was able to respond to mention of Romney's dog strapped to the car roof. Now I need another trigger for my comment on taxing the rich. Maybe it is zombies.

Since this column is about zombies, I can safely say that the rich should be taxed at a higher rate than today. In fact, they should be taxed at the same rate as the rest of us. Unless you agree with Lincoln, in which case they should be taxed more.

Specifically, taxes on unearned income should be at least equal to taxes on earned income. At present they are about half, so the rich pay about half the tax rate on their income that us middle class workaholics do.

And this is despite the fact that most (80%) of their wealth is inherited. So it does not reflect hard work on the part of the taxpayer, and may in fact reflect booze-laden indolence. And despite the fact that an additional dollar of income to wealthy people produces less economic activity that an extra buck to a poor person produces.

All right, I will concede that capital gains should be adjusted for inflation before being taxed, but only if earned income is also deflated in the same way. And of course Tom Jefferson passed legislation to restrict inheritance (entailment) which probably should be revived.

Flynn may be correct about measured I.Q. (I hope he takes account of the continual readjustment of I.Q. standards.) However, your own sentences,

"... I confess to doubts about the Flynn Effect when I contemplate the slide from Shakespeare to “Fifty Shades of Grey.” Likewise, politics does not seem to benefit: One academic study found a deterioration in the caliber of discussions of economics in presidential debates from 1960 to 2008."

along with the evident decrease in the complexity of grammar and vocabulary in political speeches over the past century plus (compare Lincoln or FDR and their contemporaries with the last Presidential debate) leave me with doubt that intelligence is truly increasing.

Mary, you have put this so well, "we might actually be more disposed to focus on things that most of us value like education, health care, living wages, a clean and healthy environment and retirement security rather than race, gender, sexual identity, ethnicity and religion."

This is where everyone's focus should be right now, especially in Washington DC.

The USA has always been known as the melting pot and the future lies with the young. Hopefully, they can ignore the past and show us how to live together as one nation, united, with, as you say, their message of acceptance and inclusion.

I certainly won't mourn the end of white men mostly running the show in DC. Change there would be a great relief.

Equity in demography may foster greater equity in educational and economic opportunities. One of the most heartening outcomes of this election was seeing the rainbow of colors, economic status and different lifestyles unite to vote for what came down basically to the issue of fairness and go on to win the presidency.

It may be a difficult transition, perhaps monumental but that old adage about "safety in numbers" may prove true. It would certainly help in leveling the playing field in giving equal voices to more groups. Those younger voices that changed the gay marriage debate will probably be just as effective in this one with their message of acceptance and inclusion.

Though it seems impossible today, we might actually be more disposed to focus on things that most of us value like education, health care, living wages, a clean and healthy environment and retirement security rather than race, gender, sexual identity, ethnicity and religion.

I welcome the changes that will come, no matter the difficulty because the status quo has become unacceptable.
